snippet: Even with the demand for seats increasing, the big airlines have not restored many of their flights, particularly on routes to small airports.
abstract: Airlines seeking to bolster profits are cutting back service to small and midsize airports, even with the demand for seats increasing, leaving passengers with longer and more complicated flight schedules; trips that may have taken a couple of hours on a nonstop flight a few years ago are often daylong journeys involving multiple flights and lots of waiting.
lead_paragraph: Even with the demand for seats increasing, the big airlines have not restored many of their flights, particularly on routes to small airports.

headline.seo: Regional Airlines Squeezed by Flight Cutbacks and Higher Fares
headline.print_headline: Flying Between Smaller Cities Is Becoming a Marathon Sport
